content: Nice!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Sujet clair, simple à comprendre et à résoudre. Super clash :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Problème simple, réalisable rapidement et très optimisable en taille de code sans être trop facile et évident

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Ce problème est réalisable assez rapidement mais n'est pas trop facile non plus ce qui est ce que l'on recherche dans un problème clashofcode. Et les tests sont explicatifs et claires.

I see that the Fastest and Shortest modes have been enabled, and also the cases have been revised. Here are my comments based on this version:

Goal section
* Please add "in the string" after "alphabetical characters".

* Please change "less" to "least".

Input section
* Please format "Line 1" in <<bold>>.

* Please format "string" as a [[variable]].

Output section
* Please mention the order of the characters.

Constraints section
* Please format "string" as a [[variable]].

* Please state the lower limit of string.length.

Cases
* Currently in all the cases the first character of the string is the least appearing letter. Please change some of the cases so that this will not always be the cases.

Thanks.

As the only mode enabled is Reverse, I'll skip commenting on the statement itself.

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Cases
* It does not matter whether the frequencies are calculated on a case-sensitive basis or not, because the strings being tested never contain the same letter which appears in both uppercase and lowercase.

Suggest you to revise some of the cases to cover such strings.

* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but remain different. Please revise the cases to achieve that and there should be no duplicate cases.

* (Just an observation.) "Characters" include space characters, but it's just a coincidence that they're never the characters to output.

Thanks.
"Case sensive" => Case sensitive
ty
Thank you i removed some duplicate test case

Sorry if I keep commenting, but my point about Output section is that, Goal section mentions "most occurring" and then "least occurring". It gives me the impression that the most occurring letter should be output first, followed by the least occurring letter.

But in fact, the requirement is exactly the opposite of that.

Hence, I would suggest the second sentence be written as:
You must print the <<least>> and <<most>> occurring alphabetical characters in the [[string]], separated with a space.

I would also suggest to add still one more pair of test and validator, where the letters to output are the same letter but in different cases (e.g. "H h", "x X").

In constraints section, the limits may be simplified as:
0 < [[string]].length ≤ 50

Thank you for your understanding.
Your comments keeps helping me to improve and understand about making a contribution. Thank you, you can keep commenting <3

Glad to hear that :)

So, would you consider adding a pair of cases as suggested, as that can test the "case-sensitive" specification? In addition, I think it makes sense that the least appearing character is NOT the first letter of the string in the new cases.
The "case-sensitive" specification is already tested by the 3rd test/validator

The thing is, almost all the cases (not just Test 3 and Validator 3) have the first character as part of the output, so they do not make good cases.

Test 3: "M" is the first character.

Validator 3: "W" is the first character.

There should be more vigorous cases which can distinguish a really working code, and a non-working code. Positions and frequencies should be more varied, and letter case should really make a difference.
Should I keep doing test with sentences that make sense or should I make tests like "iudthsindnnii" ?
It should be possible to write tests that are vigorous and make sense at the same time.
Ok I will take more time to find better tests that make sense
I updated the second and third test.

May I suggest to add the cases as follows? They cover (a) case-sensitiveness, and (b) all frequencies are at least 2.

Test 6:
Peter Piper still picked pickled peppers

Validator 6:
nick CLICKS and clicks and clicks and CLICKS
I added it, any other thig that I can do to improve my post?

Thanks!

One more thing, could you please change Test 5 and Validator 5 slightly as follows?

Stay focuS on your thingS
Least appearing is not first LOL

This is because there are currently no cases where the most frequent letter is in uppercase.

I think that's about it after this change! :)
Ok I'm changing this! Thanks for all the help you provided!!
Do you think I shoud replace "a b" by "most least" in the base code provided or would it be too simple?

It depends on how difficult you want the clash in Reverse mode to be. You may also want to hear others' views on this issue. Personally I don't have any preference. However, if you do want to change it, it should be "least most" instead of "most least". :wink:

XD my bad little mistake. 
No relation but how did you get the success "Puzzle of the week"?

CodinGame used to feature a puzzle every week. It has stopped doing so now. However, the final puzzle chosen still shows the label:
https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/lets-make-a-cheap-ascii-3d-engine

I don't know whether doing that puzzle will earn you that achievement. Maybe you can try and tell me the result :P

If you have further questions unrelated to this contribution, you may PM me in the forum or on Discord.
Thanks. Each pair should be similar while different too, e.g. Test 1 and Validator 1, Test 2 and Validator 2, etc.
Like each pair must test the same thing with different inputs?

The point of validators is to prevent hardcoding by the players, because tests are visible to the clash players, while validators are not.

At the same time, you would want validators not to create any nasty surprise to the players if validators cover something not covered in the tests.

So the general logic of designing test cases would be:
• simpler cases first, more complex cases later
• each pair of test and validator is similar.

For example:
Both Test 1 and Validator 1 cover strings in lowercase only and with clear frequency distinctions (e.g. Test 1 may be "abbcccddddeeeee", Validator 1 may be "hhhhffgggiiiiiijjjjj".

Both Test 2 and Validator 2 cover strings in lowercase only and with some frequencies being the same (e.g. Test 2 may be "hello world", Validator 2 may be "nice and cool").

Both Test 3 and Validator 3 cover strings in lowercase and uppercase.

Both Test 4 and Validator 4 cover strings with many frequencies being the same.

And you can have more than 4 pairs of cases if necessary - it's absolutely ok.

Hope this helps. Feel free to ask if you have any other questions.
Also as this clash is Reverse mode only, you would want to make sure that the visible tests give enough hints/scenarios to the players so that they can figure out what to do.
